definitions: accompany and protect a group of vehicles or ships traveling together
examples: Navy ships convoy merchant vessels through dangerous waters
Armed vehicles will convoy the supply trucks to base

definitions: make the low soft cry of a dove or pigeon
speak in a soft gentle loving way especially to babies
examples: Pigeons coo softly on the windowsill every morning
The doves coo in the trees outside our bedroom
Parents coo sweet words to their newborn babies
She cooed lovingly at the tiny infant

definitions: bring different elements of a complex activity or organization into an efficient relationship
make different things work or look good together by matching or arranging them
examples: The manager coordinates all departments for the product launch
Teachers coordinate their lesson plans for better student learning
She coordinates her outfit colors perfectly every day
Interior designers coordinate furniture and decorations in each room

definitions: perform a lively dance characterized by kicking movements popular in the 1920s
examples: They charleston enthusiastically at the vintage dance party
Grandma still knows how to charleston from her youth

definitions: cover or coat something with a layer of copper metal
examples: The craftsman will copper the bottom of the cooking pot
They copper electrical wires to improve conductivity

definitions: engage in sexual intercourse as animals or humans for reproduction or pleasure
examples: Many animals copulate only during specific mating seasons
The nature documentary showed lions copulating in the wild

definitions: close or seal a bottle or container with a piece of cork
examples: The winemaker corks each bottle by hand carefully
Please cork the wine bottle tightly after pouring

definitions: move or twist in a spiral pattern like a corkscrew tool
examples: The airplane corkscrews through the air during aerobatic shows
The drill bit corkscrews deep into the wooden board

definitions: gather and confine animals or people into a fenced area or restricted space
examples: Cowboys corral the horses into the pen for feeding
Teachers corral students into the gymnasium during fire drills

definitions: have a mutual relationship or connection where one thing affects or depends on another
examples: Study hours correlate strongly with higher test scores
Scientists correlate weather patterns with climate change data

definitions: have a close similarity or match with something else in nature or character
communicate by exchanging letters or emails regularly with someone
examples: The suspect's story doesn't correspond with witness accounts
These results correspond exactly to our initial predictions
Pen pals correspond weekly sharing news about their lives
The soldiers correspond with family members back home

definitions: confirm or give support to a statement or theory with additional evidence or testimony
examples: Multiple witnesses corroborate the victim's version of events
Scientific data corroborates the researcher's original hypothesis

definitions: dress up and act as a fictional character from movies games or comics
examples: Fans cosplay their favorite anime characters at conventions
She cosplays as Wonder Woman at comic book events

definitions: suddenly force air from the lungs with a harsh sound to clear throat or when sick
examples: People cough frequently during cold and flu season
Please cough into your elbow to prevent spreading germs

definitions: accept approve or give support to something especially reluctantly
examples: The principal will not countenance bullying in school
Parents rarely countenance their children staying out past midnight

definitions: act against something to reduce its force or neutralize its harmful effects
examples: This medicine counteracts the poison in your system
Exercise counteracts the negative effects of sitting all day

definitions: make an attack in response to one by an enemy or opponent
examples: The army counterattacks after defending their position all night
Chess players counterattack when their opponent makes aggressive moves

definitions: have an equal and opposite effect on something to create balance or stability
examples: Her optimism counterbalances his tendency to worry excessively
Weights counterbalance the elevator to make it operate smoothly

definitions: make an exact imitation of something valuable with the intention to deceive
examples: Criminals counterfeit money using sophisticated printing equipment
Some companies counterfeit designer handbags to sell cheaply

definitions: provide a pleasing or notable contrast to something else
examples: The bright colors counterpoint the dark background beautifully
Her calm demeanor counterpoints his energetic personality perfectly

definitions: balance something by applying an opposing weight or force
examples: Engineers counterweight the crane to prevent it from tipping
The architect counterweights the structure for better stability

definitions: agree to a formal binding agreement especially in religious or legal contexts
examples: The nations covenant to reduce carbon emissions by half
Members covenant to follow all church rules and teachings

definitions: walk sideways or in an awkward way like a crab
complain about something in a bad-tempered way
examples: The car crabs sideways on the icy road surface
Rock climbers crab along the narrow ledge carefully
Neighbors crab about the noise from construction work daily
He crabs endlessly about having to work on weekends

definitions: make a rapid series of short sharp noises like burning wood
examples: The campfire crackles warmly on the cold winter night
Autumn leaves crackle underfoot as children play outside

definitions: hold gently and protectively in one's arms or hands
examples: Mothers cradle their newborn babies with infinite tenderness
The nurse cradles the injured bird before treating it

definitions: force too many things or people into a space that is too small
study intensively over a short time before an examination
examples: Commuters cram into subway cars during morning rush hour
Don't cram all your clothes into one small suitcase
Students cram all night before their final examinations
She crams vocabulary words the morning of language tests

definitions: prevent free movement or development by being too tight or restrictive
examples: These tight shoes cramp my toes when I walk
Small apartments cramp our lifestyle with three growing children

definitions: stretch out one's neck to see something better
examples: Spectators crane their necks to see the parade floats
Students crane forward trying to read the board

definitions: turn a handle or lever to operate a machine or device
produce something quickly and mechanically without much care or thought
examples: Grandfather still cranks the old ice cream maker by hand
Drivers crank their windows down on hot summer days
The factory cranks out thousands of toys every day
Writers crank out articles to meet their weekly deadlines

definitions: pack something in a wooden box or container for storage or transport
examples: Workers crate fragile artwork before shipping to museums
The company crates fresh produce for international delivery

definitions: feel a powerful desire for something especially food or experiences
examples: Pregnant women often crave unusual food combinations at night
After months abroad, travelers crave familiar home cooking

definitions: draw or color with wax sticks made for coloring
examples: Children crayon colorful pictures during art class time
The toddler crayons on paper instead of the walls

definitions: produce a network of fine cracks on a surface
examples: Heat and cold craze the glaze on antique pottery
Time will craze the paint on outdoor furniture

definitions: make a line or fold in something especially fabric or paper
examples: Iron carefully to avoid creasing your dress shirt collar
Students crease paper precisely when making origami figures

definitions: move slowly and carefully to avoid being heard or noticed
gradually increase or advance beyond the usual or desirable point
examples: The cat creeps silently toward the unsuspecting bird
Children creep downstairs on Christmas morning to see presents
Prices creep higher every year without people noticing
Doubt creeps into her mind about the decision

definitions: gradually increase in loudness or intensity until reaching a peak
examples: The music crescendos dramatically during the final movement
Applause crescendos as the performer takes her final bow

definitions: reach the top of something especially a hill or wave
examples: Hikers crest the mountain just as sunrise begins
Surfers wait for waves to crest before riding them

definitions: copy another person's work dishonestly and pass it off as original
examples: Students who crib answers during exams face serious consequences
Don't crib your essay from internet sources

definitions: cause a painful stiff feeling in the neck or back
examples: Sleeping in awkward positions cricks your neck painfully
Looking up too long cricks my neck every time

definitions: make an activity illegal by passing laws against it
examples: Many countries criminalize drug possession with severe penalties
Governments criminalize certain behaviors to protect public safety

definitions: compress something into small folds or ridges
have a limiting or negative effect on something
examples: Bakers crimp the edges of pie crusts for decoration
Hair stylists crimp hair to create textured wavy styles
Rising costs crimp the company's expansion plans this year
New regulations crimp small business growth and innovation

definitions: become bright red in color especially from embarrassment or shame
examples: Her cheeks crimson when everyone sings happy birthday
His face crimsons after making the embarrassing mistake

definitions: bend one's body in fear or apprehension of something
experience an inward feeling of embarrassment or disgust
examples: Dogs cringe when they hear loud thunder or fireworks
Children cringe away from the doctor holding a needle
Parents cringe watching their teenager's awkward dance performance
We cringe remembering our fashion choices from high school

definitions: cause severe damage to something making it unable to function properly
examples: Computer viruses can cripple entire business networks overnight
The storm will cripple power systems across the region

definitions: make something firm dry and brittle especially by cooking
examples: The chef crisps bacon until it's perfectly golden brown
Cold weather crisps the fallen leaves in autumn

definitions: indicate the faults of someone or something in a disapproving way
examples: Film reviewers criticise movies that lack original storytelling
Parents shouldn't criticise children's efforts when they're learning

definitions: create fabric by interlocking loops of yarn with a hooked needle
examples: Grandmother crochets warm blankets for all her grandchildren
Many people crochet while watching television in the evening

definitions: bend something especially a finger or arm
examples: She crooks her finger to beckon someone over
The shepherd crooks his arm around the lamb's neck

definitions: hum or sing in a soft low voice especially in a sentimental manner
examples: Mothers croon lullabies to help babies fall asleep
The singer croons romantic ballads at the jazz club

definitions: adopt a position where the knees are bent and the upper body brought forward
examples: Players crouch in ready position before the race begins
The photographer crouches to get the perfect angle shot
